ai_diag.summary: A 38-year-old female presents with a persistent cough, frontal headache suggestive of sinus pressure, and an audible rumbling noise on deep inspiration, without prior diagnostic testing. She has moderate physical activity, a paleo diet, and reports significant work-related stress and anxiety.

ratings.comments: A good suggestion that should be further investigated.
Further investigation about acute bronchitis should be done.
A very common issue that should be investigated.
A very coherent suggestion to check the patient's sinus.
This is a good suggestion. It should reveal any lung accumulated secretion.

ai_exam.summary: The patient’s symptoms of nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, facial pressure, cough and sputum production may reflect overlapping acute sinusitis, acute bronchitis and allergic rhinitis. Acute sinusitis typically presents with facial pain/pressure, purulent discharge and nasal obstruction lasting >10 days or worsening after initial improvement. Acute bronchitis is characterized by a cough (often productive) following a viral prodrome, usually without consolidation on chest imaging. Allergic rhinitis causes sneezing, itching, clear rhinorrhea and pale, boggy nasal mucosa. Differentiating these conditions guides appropriate management—bacterial vs viral, airway assessment and identification of allergic triggers.

ai_diag.summary: A 52-year-old female presents with 6 weeks of progressively worsening low back pain radiating to the right buttock, aggravated by prolonged standing and lifting. She reports no bowel/bladder changes but notes occasional right leg tingling. She works as a nurse and has a history of intermittent back pain episodes.

ai_exam.summary: Lumbar strain typically presents with localized pain and muscle spasms. Radicular symptoms suggest nerve root compression from disc herniation or stenosis. Red flags include bowel/bladder dysfunction, progressive neurological deficits, or history of malignancy. Most cases are mechanical and improve with conservative management; imaging is reserved for red flags or persistent symptoms.

patient.symptoms: low back pain radiating to right buttock, occasional right leg tingling

ratings.comments: A reasonable primary consideration given the physical activity and occupational context.
Likely contributing factor given age and history, deserves attention.
Excellent first-line imaging to assess disc pathology and rule out serious issues.
Essential component of conservative management for mechanical back pain.

patient.symptoms: intermittent chest discomfort, shortness of breath during exertion, occasional palpitations
patient.mental_health: generally stable, mild anxiety before presentations

ai_diag.summary: A 29-year-old male presents with intermittent chest discomfort, exertional shortness of breath, and occasional palpitations. He maintains regular physical activity and follows a vegetarian diet. His mental health is generally stable, with mild anxiety under pressure. No prior diagnostic evaluations have been performed.

ratings.comments: This diagnosis is plausible given the symptoms and should be evaluated further.
Fits some symptoms, such as palpitations and chest discomfort.
Highly relevant considering exertional symptoms in a young adult.
A basic but essential test for evaluating cardiac symptoms.
Useful to detect structural heart disease like mitral valve prolapse or HCM.
Important to assess symptoms during exertion and rule out angina.

ai_exam.summary: The symptoms suggest possible structural or functional cardiac issues such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or mitral valve prolapse. An ECG can detect arrhythmias, an echocardiogram assesses structural abnormalities, and a stress test helps evaluate exercise-induced symptoms. These tests provide a comprehensive initial workup for young patients with exertional symptoms and no prior testing.
options: Blood tests including troponin and BNP
